response:
Imaging of the brain, orbits and spinal cord is required urgently to define the central lesions, distinguish demyelinating, vascular and compressive causes, and guide acute treatment. Neurophysiology will characterise the peripheral neuropathy. Blood tests should search for reversible myeloneuropathies (especially vitamin B12 and copper deficiency) and systemic autoimmune, metabolic or infectious causes. CSF and antibody studies help confirm or exclude inflammatory demyelinating diseases such as multiple sclerosis and neuromyelitis optica. Vascular investigations are included because a parasagittal infarct remains a differential.
